head.title: Be Certain Mars Has No Dinosaurs

hedline.hl1: Be Certain Mars Has No Dinosaurs

block.p: The project to make Mars habitable by terraforming should not be ridiculed, as some scientists are doing ("Can Mars Be Made Hospitable to Humans?", Science Times, Oct. 1). Its proponents would warm up the red planet by creating a greenhouse effect.

This is in fact the way Earth was made habitable. An econometric model prepared on Venus in approximately 200,000,000 B.C. has recently been discovered in a cave in Colorado and is now being analyzed in our university's computers.

The project to make Mars habitable by terraforming should not be ridiculed, as some scientists are doing ("Can Mars Be Made Hospitable to Humans?", Science Times, Oct. 1). Its proponents would warm up the red planet by creating a greenhouse effect.

This is in fact the way Earth was made habitable. An econometric model prepared on Venus in approximately 200,000,000 B.C. has recently been discovered in a cave in Colorado and is now being analyzed in our university's computers.

Faced with the destruction of their own planet through irreversible global warming, Venusian economists calculated the costs and benefits of heating up a barren Earth. The exact path of economic and social development was charted, including the evolution of democracy, socialism and the size of government deficits. When all this had been done, a massive space lift brought the inhabitants of Venus to Earth.
Unfortunately, they were all eaten by dinosaurs, and human evolution had to start again.
The moral: No econometric model is perfect. JOHN P. POWELSON Prof. of Economics, U. of Colorado Boulder, Colo., Oct. 4, 1991
